sen.j: 白米（はくまい）とは、玄米を精米（精米機、搗精）した米のこと。
sen.e: Hakumai (White rice) refers to polished (seimai, also called seihaku or tosei) brown rice.
sen.cmt: 「精米機」はリンク先の単語で原文は「精白」となっているのでそちらで訳出。
sen.e: Hakumai (white rice) is polished brown rice.
sen.cmt: Simplified, as the Japanese terms are confusing as they currently appear. Terms moved to cell F7.
sen.e: Hakumai (white rice) is polished brown rice.

sen.j: 精米、精白米ともいう。
sen.e: It is also called seimai (polished rice) or seihakumai (polished white rice).
It is also called seimai (polished rice) or seihakumai (polished white rice).
It is also called seimai (polished rice) or seihakumai (polished white rice).

sen.j: 精米という語は精白する事と共に出来た白米の意味でも使われる。
sen.e: The term seimai is used as the meaning of polishing as well as white rice to be made.
The term seimai is used to mean the act of polishing the rice as well as the white rice itself; other expressions for the act of polishing include seihaku and tosei.
The term seimai is used to mean the act of polishing the rice as well as the white rice itself; other expressions for the act of polishing include seihaku and tosei.

sen.j: 名前の通り、原料の玄米より白っぽく、透明感がある。
sen.e: As the name shows, it is whiter and more transparent than brown rice as its raw material.
As the name implies, it is whiter and more transparent than the brown rice it comes from.
As the name implies, it is whiter and more transparent than the brown rice it comes from.

sen.j: 炊いて飯としたり、加工食品や清酒の原料にもする。
sen.e: It is cooked for eating and also used as the ingredient for processed food and seishu (refined sake).
It is cooked both for eating directly and also used as an ingredient in processed food and seishu (refined sake).
It is cooked both for eating directly and also used as an ingredient in processed food and seishu (refined sake).

sen.j: 平成元年（1989年）11月22日 国税庁告示第8号「清酒の製法品質表示基準を定める件」により以下のとおり定められている。
sen.e: It is defined as below by the National Tax Agency Notification 8, November 22, 1989 'Standard for Process Quality Indication of Seishu.'
The 'Standard for Seishu Production Process Quality Indications' is defined in the following way by Japanese National Tax Agency Notification 8, of November 22, 1989.
sen.cmt: Order changed, grammar, punctuation. 'Japanese' added for benefit of non-Japanese readers.
sen.e: The 'Standard for Seishu Production Process Quality Indications' is defined in the following way by Japanese National Tax Agency Notification 8, of November 22, 1989.

sen.j: 「白米とは、農産物検査法(昭和26年（1951年）法律第144号)により、3等以上に格付けされた玄米又はこれに相当する玄米を精米したものをいうものとする。」
sen.e: Hakumai shall refer to polished the brown rice ranked as the third grade or higher by Agricultural Products Inspection Act (Act 144, 1951) or the equivalent brown rice.'
Hakumai shall refer to polished brown rice ranked as third grade or higher by the Agricultural Products Inspection Act (Act 144, 1951) or equivalent brown rice".
Hakumai shall refer to polished brown rice ranked as third grade or higher by the Agricultural Products Inspection Act (Act 144, 1951) or equivalent brown rice.'
sen.cmt: " "を' 'に変更してピリオドを' '内に移動させました。

sen.j: 玄米は圧力釜でない普通の炊飯器で炊くと糠層の消化が悪く、食感もぼそぼそで悪い。
sen.e: When brown rice is cooked with a normal rice cooker, not a pressure cooker, its rice bran layer is difficult to digest, and the texture is dry and poor.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: When brown rice is cooked in a normal rice cooker rather than a pressure cooker, its rice bran layer is difficult to digest, and the texture is dry and poor.
When brown rice is cooked in a normal rice cooker rather than a pressure cooker, its rice bran layer is difficult to digest, and the texture is dry and poor.

sen.j: それに比べ、白米を炊いた飯は消化も食感も良く旨い。
sen.e: In contrast, the cooked white rice is good for digestion and in texture, and delicious.
In contrast, cooked white rice is good for the digestion, has a better texture, and is considered more delicious.
In contrast, cooked white rice is good for the digestion, has a better texture, and is considered more delicious.

sen.j: 圧力釜で炊いた玄米に比べると味が淡白で、主食として副食料理に合う。
sen.e: Compared to brown rice cooked with a pressure cooker, its taste is light, which matches supplementary dishes as staple food.
Compared to brown rice cooked in a pressure cooker, it has a light taste which goes well with accompanying dishes as a staple food.
Compared to brown rice cooked in a pressure cooker, it has a light taste which goes well with accompanying dishes as a staple food.

sen.j: 砂糖の黒砂糖と上白糖と同様である。
sen.e: This is similar to brown sugar and white superior soft sugar.
This is similar to the difference between brown sugar and white superior soft sugar.
This is similar to the difference between brown sugar and white superior soft sugar.

sen.j: デンプン以外の栄養素は擦り落とされた胚芽と糠層に多く、胚乳のみの白米は栄養的に偏っている。
sen.e: The nutrition other than starch is full in germ and bran layer scraped off, so white rice only with albumen is not well balanced nutritionally.
The germ and bran layer which is scraped off is full of nutrition, so white rice which contains only starch and albumen is not well balanced nutritionally.
The germ and bran layer which is scraped off is full of nutrition, so white rice which contains only starch and albumen is not well balanced nutritionally.

sen.j: 「美味しいご飯があればおかずは要らない」等と言う人がいるが、栄養的に可能でない。
sen.e: Though some people say things like 'I wouldn't need accompanying dishes if I had good rice,' it is not possible nutritionally.
Though people have been known to say 'I wouldn't need any other type of food if I had good rice' this is not possible nutritionally.
Though people have been known to say 'I wouldn't need any other type of food if I had good rice' this is not possible nutritionally.

sen.j: 米飯は、デンプンの割合が多い程、食感に日本人好みの粘りがある。
sen.e: The more it has starch, the more the cooked rice has stickiness the Japanese like in texture.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: The more starch in the rice, the stickier the cooked rice becomes, and the more favorable to the palate of the average Japanese consumer.
The more starch in the rice, the stickier the cooked rice becomes, and the more favorable to the palate of the average Japanese consumer.

sen.j: 良食味米はタンパク質等のデンプン以外の成分が更に少ない。
sen.e: Delicious rice has much less components other than starch such as protein.
Such 'delicious rice' has far fewer components other than starch, such as protein.
Such 'delicious rice' has far fewer components other than starch, such as protein.

sen.j: 精米後の白米は、皮をはがれた状態であり、日数の経過と共に酸化等により劣化していく。
sen.e: The white rice after polishing is in the condition of being stripped, so it deteriorates due to oxidation and so on as days go by.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: White rice has had the outer layer removed during the polishing process, so it deteriorates more easily due to oxidation as days go by.
White rice has had the outer layer removed during the polishing process, so it deteriorates more easily due to oxidation as days go by.

sen.j: そのため、少しずつ購入する方が新鮮である。
sen.e: Therefore it is more fresh to purchase little by little.
Therefore people usually purchase it in comparatively small amounts to maintain freshness.
Therefore people usually purchase it in comparatively small amounts to maintain freshness.

sen.j: 低温貯蔵がより望ましい。
sen.e: Cold storage is preferable.
Cold storage is preferable.
Cold storage is preferable.

sen.j: 古くは臼で搗いた米を舂米（しょうまい/つきしね/つきよね、「春」ではない）と呼んだ。
sen.e: The rice pounded by a mortar was called 舂米 (shomai/tsukishine/tsukiyone, not '春') in earlier times.

In earlier times rice pounded by a mortar was called 舂米 (pronounced shomai, tsukishine or tsukiyone, the first character of which is not to be confused with the similar looking character for spring '春').
sen.cmt: Order changed, punctuation, explanation added for clarity.
sen.e: In earlier times rice pounded by a mortar was called 舂米 (pronounced shomai, tsukishine or tsukiyone, the first character of which is not to be confused with the similar looking character for spring '春').

sen.j: 古代には女性が臼と杵を使って作業を行い、大和朝廷の屯倉には特に舂米部（しょうまいべ）を置いたと伝えられている。
sen.e: It is said that, in ancient times, women worked with a mortar and pestle, and the department of shomai was especially established in the miyake (Imperial-controlled territory) in the Yamato Dynasty.
It is said that, in ancient times, women worked with a mortar and pestle, and a Department of Shomai was especially established in the miyake (Imperial-controlled territory) in the Yamato Dynasty.
It is said that, in ancient times, women worked with a mortar and pestle, and a Department of Shomai was especially established in the miyake (Imperial-controlled territory) in the Yamato Dynasty.

sen.j: 明治までは一般庶民は白米を食うことを制限されていた。
sen.e: Ordinary people were constrained from eating white rice before the Meiji Period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: Ordinary people were constrained from eating white rice before the Meiji Period.
Ordinary people were constrained from eating white rice before the Meiji Period.

sen.j: が、明治にこれが撤廃されたため、庶民は白米を食うようになった。
sen.e: But this was abolished in the Meiji Period, and ordinary people started to eat white rice.
But the abolition of this rule in the Meiji Period, meant that ordinary people could also start to eat white rice.
But the abolition of this rule in the Meiji Period, meant that ordinary people could also start to eat white rice.

sen.j: しかし経済的に恵まれない層は不足する栄養素を補うためのおかずにまで手が回らなかった。
sen.e: However, the economically-challenged were not able to manage accompanying dishes to compensate for the loss of nutrients.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: However, the economically-challenged were not able to afford enough accompanying dishes to compensate for the loss of nutrients from eating white rice.
However, the economically-challenged were not able to afford enough accompanying dishes to compensate for the loss of nutrients from eating white rice.

sen.j: そのためにひと頃は脚気が国民病とまで言われたことがある。
sen.e: So it was once said that beriberi was a national disease.
For this reason it was once said that beriberi was the Japanese national disease.
sen.cmt: Added for clarity, and for benefit of non-Japanese readers.
sen.e: For this reason it was once said that beriberi was the Japanese national disease.

sen.j: 国内では、玄米をそのまま消費するのは稀である。
sen.e: In Japan, it is rare to consume brown rice as it is.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: In Japan, it is rare to consume brown rice as it is.
In Japan, it is rare to consume brown rice as it is.

sen.j: 精米して白米と米糠に分け、それぞれ販売され利用されてきた。
sen.e: It has been polished and divided into white rice and rice bran, and sold and used respectively.
Rice is overwhemingly polished and divided into white rice and rice bran, and sold and used respectively.
Rice is overwhelmingly polished and divided into white rice and rice bran, and sold and used respectively.
sen.cmt: overwhemingly をoverwhelmingly に変更しました。

sen.j: 普通の玄米より普通の炊飯器で炊くのに適した発芽玄米も登場した。
sen.e: Sprouted brown rice, which suits for cooking with a normal rice cooker better than normal brown rice, has appeared.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の原則の例外対処
sen.e: Sprouted brown rice, which suits being cooked in a normal rice cooker better than standard brown rice, has recently appeared on the market.
Sprouted brown rice, which suits being cooked in a normal rice cooker better than standard brown rice, has recently appeared on the market.

sen.j: が、消費者への小売りでは白米がデファクトスタンダードとして確立している。
sen.e: But white rice has been established as de facto standard in retail for consumers.
But white rice has been established as the de facto standard in retail for consumers.
But white rice has been established as the de facto standard in retail for consumers.
